All your machines will communicate with each other, and back to their home offices, reporting everything from diagnostic status to usage profiles.This has nothing to do with “Big Brother” and a surveillance state, and everything to do with supply chain management and the profits to be made by squeezing out every middle step.In 30 years, there won’t be a thing called a “warehouse”, there will only be factory-direct-to-consumer “distribution centers”.The infrastructure for this is being built today, 30 years from now it will be as established and consistent as the interstate higheay system is today.

Answer: You don’t advance technology as a monolith. Germany is a leader in material science and mechanical engineering.Germany is sub-par in software engineering and in its physical communication infrastructure. This is in part due to persistent cultural wariness of surveillance technologies like social media. People aren’t keen to fund the infrastructure to make mass surveillance easier, and politicians don’t want to be seen as pushing for the capability.Germany also has the capability to advance nuclear technology, but doesn’t due to mass scientific illiteracy among the voting population that falselYou don’t advance technology as a monolith. Germany is a leader in material science and mechanical engineering.Germany is sub-par in software engineering and in its physical communication infrastructure. This is in part due to persistent cultural wariness of surveillance technologies like social media. People aren’t keen to fund the infrastructure to make mass surveillance easier, and politicians don’t want to be seen as pushing for the capability.Germany also has the capability to advance nuclear technology, but doesn’t due to mass scientific illiteracy among the voting population that falsely believes nuclear energy to be more dangerous than fossil fuels due to decades of propaganda by idiots.So no. Germany is not the most technologically advanced country. It could be pretty close, but there are major elements of society who dedicate themselves to making sure that Germany uses inferior technology that kills more people, damages the environment more, costs more money, and will cause the total collapse of Earth’s biosphere due to a runaway greenhouse effect. Mostly in the Green Party. Because radiation from nuclear accidents is apparently scarier than way more people dying of regular pollution constantly and the total annihilation of all life on Earth as the oceans boil away.

The brain is capable of juggling far more complexity than reading a book while squeezing through a crowd, checking for open doors, scanning for vagrants, anWalking an chewing gum at the same time.I'm a writer. I'm also a busy professional. I hardly ever go anywhere without my computer and an e-reader. If I can sit, I write. If I can't, I read. The idea of wasting a perfectly good ten minute walk through the tunnels of Houston when I could be reading has become nearly unthinkable to me.Yet, I constantly meet people (mostly older) who warn me I'm going to walk into something. Of course I'm not. The brain is capable of juggling far more complexity than reading a book while squeezing through a crowd, checking for open doors, scanning for vagrants, and checking out the occasional rear end.Brains can multitask.

Answer: I think one skill that is already becoming more and more universal is highly skilled content creation. Like you mentioned, a few years ago it was impressive enough just to browse the web, send an email, and maybe have a personal blog or website. Today all that stuff is standard fare - everyone does it a thousand times a day.But what's becoming more and more common, especially with youngsters, is content creation. Now if you want to add your voice to a conversation, you download the latest meme pic, open it in photoshop and add your own personal touch to it. You reskin your wordpress blog withI think one skill that is already becoming more and more universal is highly skilled content creation. Like you mentioned, a few years ago it was impressive enough just to browse the web, send an email, and maybe have a personal blog or website. Today all that stuff is standard fare - everyone does it a thousand times a day.But what's becoming more and more common, especially with youngsters, is content creation. Now if you want to add your voice to a conversation, you download the latest meme pic, open it in photoshop and add your own personal touch to it. You reskin your wordpress blog with your own custom CSS. You take your favorite song and make a remix of it.As we become more comfortable with the technology as a tool, we are able to use it with greater ease. It wouldn't surprise me at all if, in ten years, everyone had basic graphic design skills, web development skills, video post-production and editing skills, and a host of other things related to creating and remixing content.

question: https://www.quora.com/What-are-some-technological-advances-you-hope-to-see-in-the-next-50-years

Answer: According to the World Health Organization, the #1 cause of death is coronary artery disease at 12.6%. The next one down is cerebrovascular disease, i.e. strokes, at 9.7%. This is effectively another disease of the circulatory system, so over 20% of all human deaths are attributable to this one cause.From this I conclude that the single technological breakthrough that would provide the biggest benefit to humanity is a treatment that safely dissolves and removes arterial plaque. A drain cleaner for the blood vessels.

question: https://www.quora.com/What-are-some-technological-advances-you-hope-to-see-in-the-next-50-years

Answer: A technology revolution is both desperately needed and highly likely to come in the area of mental health. This is true for three reasons: (i) mental health has reached crisis status, (ii) mental health is a booming area of medical research with high levels of tech transfer from academic labs, and (iii) brain technology is benefiting greatly from tech advances in other fields.Mental Health Crisis1A technology revolution is both desperately needed and highly likely to come in the area of mental health. This is true for three reasons: (i) mental health has reached crisis status, (ii) mental health is a booming area of medical research with high levels of tech transfer from academic labs, and (iii) brain technology is benefiting greatly from tech advances in other fields.Mental Health Crisis1 in 5 American adults experience a mental illness. [1] [2] This number is likely to be higher in developing nations. If you live past the age of 60 you have a nearly 30% chance of being killed by some form of dementia.  [3]The prevailing theory used to posit that alleviating socioeconomic hardships would drive down all diseases; while this is true for many diseases of the last century, by virtue of longer life-spans other diseases have emerged, most famously: dementia. Other mental health challenges are also on the rise—Those suffering from Autism Spectral Disorder make up approximately 1 in 132 individuals (and growing) [4], 1–3 of every 100 will experience epileptic seizures in their lifetime,  [5]and a whopping 1 in 10 with mood disorders [6].Biomedical Research: Focus on the BrainIn 2011 nearly a quarter of the National Institutes of Health $32B budget went to ‘neurosciences’ related projects.  [7]The proportion of brain work through this agency has bloomed following new initiatives focusing on breakthrough technological advances from the field [8].While some areas of basic research have legitimate reasons to complain about stagnating funding, medical research cannot. The NIH currently provides 50% greater funding than it did in the year 2000. Much of this growth has occurred in brain research. That being said, it is also easy to say that it isn’t enough to meet the demand and needs of those afflicted with debilitating disease. When the quality of life of 1 in 5 humans is on the line, mental health issues should continue to take a front and center position among public policy issues. That is all I will say about...

Answer: Science fiction writers predicted just about everything we currently have.It is very easy to predict the future. The writer of fairy  tales did it hundreds of years ago.Magic mirror on the wall, who is fairest of them all?Flying carpets, horses, magic boots? Get from A to B. We'll invent something.All you have to do to predict the future is observe a need.We produce more food than we can eat, so we need better distribution.Science fiction writers predicted just about everything we currently have.It is very easy to predict the future. The writer of fairy  tales did it hundreds of years ago.Magic mirror on the wall, who is fairest of them all?Flying carpets, horses, magic boots? Get from A to B. We'll invent something.All you have to do to predict the future is observe a need.We produce more food than we can eat, so we need better distribution.All the above issues are being addressed on a daily basis.At what point will body implants be a matter of course?To some extent scientific breakthroughs have to wait for the laws and attitudes to change before they can be marketed.To some extent vested interests will stop breakthroughs being developed.To some extent fashion will dictate what succeeds.It also depends on your status.For most people changes are almost imperceptable. The difference between an analogue watch and a digital one is irrelevant to most people.Paying with a credit card or paying cash serves the service more than the customer.A totally new form of energy will not change the world for those who just switch it on an off.Breakthroughs are relevant to the user when they have a personal application. Health is probably the main area where we will be aware of them.To that extent the fact that we are all going to become Cyborgs within the next fifty years is something that will come as a shock to many.The implications are many. On death we will be harvested for the machines and implants in our bodies.We will have less fear of death in the knowledge that we live on in a dissected afterlife. And also in the knowledge that we are not forgotten.The morals and philosophies embedded in our social mores will need reassessing.In all, it will be breakthroughs in Social attitudes that will change our lives forever.

Answer: The big game-changer would be the arrival of true artificial intelligence, or maybe we should say: intelligence and consciousness based on non-biological substrates. There would be nothing “artificial” about the intelligence as such.Dismissing religious ideas about “souls”, consciousness and intelligence must be regarded as emergent properties of information-processing units of a certain kind. So far, these thinking units have all been biological brains, just like for long ages all flying things on this planet were biological entities. In the last few centuries, non-biological flight was achieThe big game-changer would be the arrival of true artificial intelligence, or maybe we should say: intelligence and consciousness based on non-biological substrates. There would be nothing “artificial” about the intelligence as such.Dismissing religious ideas about “souls”, consciousness and intelligence must be regarded as emergent properties of information-processing units of a certain kind. So far, these thinking units have all been biological brains, just like for long ages all flying things on this planet were biological entities. In the last few centuries, non-biological flight was achieved through human technology, and soon far surpassed biology. No bird is even close to the power or speed of a jetplane, and human-made flying things have even done what no biological being ever managed: to leave this planet altogether and venture out into space.What happened with flying things may happen once more, this time withThe human brain has 86 billion neurons. To fully emulate the function of one neuron you need about the same processing power as one laptop of today. On supercomputer level, we are getting close to the processing power that would be needed to recreate the function of a human brain in real time. Around mid-century, in past trends hold, this kind of processing power should be quite trivial — about as common as a smartphone of today.And there is no reason to stop with emulations of a mere 86 billion neurons. Human brains can only get so big and no bigger, for at the end of the day, a baby’s head must actually be able to pass through a woman’s vagina without both mother and child dying in the process. (Our species already has some of the hardest births of all earthly biology, a painful tradeoff that is the price of human intelligence.) But minds existing on computer substrates would have no such limitations.What unimaginable levels of consciousness and intelligence would emerge if a mind based on aThis is the potential
